Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: An external inspector has raised immediate concerns that could halt operations unless issues are resolved
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I stared at the inspector’s report, my heart pounding. The flagged safety issue was serious—if I didn’t address it right now, the plant could be shut down for days. My manager’s voice echoed in my head: “We can’t afford downtime. Make sure everything’s compliant.” I knew what was at stake, not just for the company, but for everyone’s jobs. But as I glanced at the clock, panic crept in. My volunteer shift started in twenty minutes, and I was the only one scheduled to open the community center. People would already be waiting outside, some of them relying on us for their only hot meal of the day. I could picture their faces, the trust they placed in me to show up. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Unlock doors by 5:00 PM.” I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of responsibility pressing down from both sides. I couldn’t let the plant down, but I couldn’t let the community down either. My hands trembled as I tried to figure out what to do next, torn between two worlds that both needed me, right now.
